I would suggest the following workflow -

Check in the current process that there is a variable PARAM_ABORT_ON_ERROR - this is done.
If there is -> get the correlation id
abort the process with the correlation id.

Benefits:

delete the whole process instance(by the correlationId) recursively(do not rely on that logic - it could be broken).
No OptimisticLockingException could rise because if we are pass here we know that there is no running executions

Drawbacks:

if there are parallel processing and we should abort - there could be an OptimisticLockingException. Check what is done in the AbortProcessAction and decide what could be done here.

Current implementation drawbacks:

OptimisticLocking would be risen if you have parallel exectuins because of this: if (rootProcessInstanceId != null && shouldAbort(commandContext, rootProcessInstanceId)) { abortProcess(commandContext, rootProcessInstanceId);
Some lefover processes will be presented because the you are not making sure that all the child executions will be deleted.
Other elements, part of the process(jobs, executions, timers, variables, etc.), are not again guaranteed to be removed as a whole because the deletion will not happen recursively from the root process element.
Why @ Lazy ? It is initialized at the startup of the deploy-service.
Because there are circular dependencies when the component is initialized eagerly
Do we want to keep this behavior? Is @ Lazy guarantees on 100% that this will not brake?

Why the two checks?
If you end up here, the process with the correlationId(the super parent) will have the variable (ABORT_ON_ERROR). So, isn't only the second check enough?
This could be renamed to AbortProcessFlowableCommandExecutor
This has naming problem from the beginning -> AbortProcessFailedJobCommandFactory
Empty comment for changing the review status
